p: The first success observed in Europe and North America in 1994 did not allow for the nihilism typical of highly endemic countries with often limited resources [ 26]. Almost all pregnant women with HIV live in sub-Saharan Africa, with their number estimated to be more than one million per year. Despite the complexity of the challenge, programs were rapidly put in place. Initially, simplified strategies were applied, such as the peripartum administration of a single dose of a non-nucleoside reverse-transcriptase inhibitor, nevirapine, and postpartum administration to children. This prophylaxis, although simplified to the extreme, reduced the risk of transmission by half but induced a particularly high rate of resistance in infected mothers and children. Remarkably, simplification of the preventive strategies was then abandoned, and they followed the European and North American recommendations [ 27]. The efficiency is intrinsically similar to that observed in the North, but two major obstacles have affected the effectiveness of such programs: the difficulty of screening pregnant women for HIV and the risk of post-natal contamination through breastfeeding.
